@dmihal @FrancescoRenziA @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ Well, the other option (especially for inter cluster communication!) is using fraud proofs like @nomadxyz_, which IMO is a great option regardless because of its single-honest-party assumption

@FrancescoRenziA @dmihal @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ Yes, the idea is to head towards using the best possible mechanism for a given chain. 

On a rollup, this means utilizing the specific benefits of a rollup AMB.

@Bisarka @pristineindigo7 @legendarymrpopo @cosmos Instead, I think cosmos is much better suited to be an important building block for web3 infra/middleware projects.

https://t.co/0uMMvZNQNg

@Bisarka @pristineindigo7 @legendarymrpopo @cosmos I don't like the "app-specific chain" marketing. It implies that cosmos applications are going to be directly competitive with Eth DeFi.

That doesn't make a lot of sense to me. It will always be 100x easier to build a DeFi application in solidity.

@pedrouid @RHLSTHRM @cosmos Not exactly - I specifically mean that there is a market for achieving consensus on things where that thing doesn't require the security or expressivity of Ethereum L1.

IMO Cosmos is really powerful for lower level infra/web3 projects that exist outside the app layer
@FrancescoRenziA @dmihal @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ Nomad + Connext will be a part of the cross-rollup experience and inherit a lot of the same core security mechanisms

The @cosmos ecosystem seems consistently criminally underrated. 

Genuinely original value prop that is distinct from being a smart contract platform or pet rock.

We are looking forward to connecting with developers and innovators in the s‚Ä¶

Tokens aren't perfect, but represent a possible sustainable model for public goods on the internet.

E.g. Search on the internet is a public good. Operating it privately (Google) leads to broken incentives and externalities (selling consumer data). https://t.co/c7CiSOE1rP

@sayinshallah The point here is that there is a class of  activities where revenue is generated (e.g. selling goods on a marketplace) and a different class of activities where a platform or public service is provided (e.g. the marketplace itself).

The corp model is totally broken for latter.

@sayinshallah This model, however is sometimes fundamentally incompatible with the products they're associated with.

Take Google search for example. Search on the internet is and needs to be public infra. No (privatized) corporate model can provide search for free forever. But a DAO could.

@sayinshallah I think driver for this is that traditional corps have to base their model on recurring revenue.

This forces their owners to capitulate and try to extract value. This can happen through platform fees, but also more exploitative means (e.g. selling user data).

@sayinshallah And even when they do get involved, control largely remains in the hands of board/PE funds.

This appears to happen to all companies. Even if founders retain control for a long period and keep the initial culture/vision alive, they will eventually be replaced (forcibly).

@sayinshallah Ive actually done a 180 on my thinking on this over the past couple of years.

Incentives for equity-based orgs drive them towards either acquisition or IPO. In both cases, there is a massive centralization risk as retail is barred from being involved until the latest stages.

@sayinshallah @blknoiz06 I think there's pretty meaningful utility to use a token to decentralize the sequencer role.

Sequencers bond token to win rights to fees for a given block - similar to the work/staking model from the Graph or Livepeer.

@iamDCinvestor That said, multisig bridges are shit for other reasons and people should stop using them immediately.

Use Connext instead.

@iamDCinvestor I'm a STRONG proponent of rollups, but I dont think what happened today is actually bullish for anything.

Rollups can not only have the same problem, but also introduce far greater attack surface around EVM execution which can also be exploited.
